block.p: Northwestern 47 Wisconsin 44
Damien Anderson's 12-yard touchdown run in the second overtime gave Northwestern a 47-44 victory over No. 7 Wisconsin yesterday in Madison, Wis.
Northwestern 47 Wisconsin 44
Damien Anderson's 12-yard touchdown run in the second overtime gave Northwestern a 47-44 victory over No. 7 Wisconsin yesterday in Madison, Wis.

''I was probably the least surprised person out of 80,000 here today,'' Northwestern Coach Randy Walker said. ''I expected to win. We don't put a plan together, or prepare or work like we work to do anything but that.''
The suspension-riddled Badgers saw their 11-game winning streak halted when Anderson scooted around left end and darted into the end zone.
Vitaly Pisetsky had given Wisconsin (3-1, 0-1 Big Ten) a 44-41 lead with a 39-yard field goal on the first possession of the second overtime.
Anderson finished with 175 yards on 21 carries for Northwestern (3-1, 1-0). He also scored on a 69-yard run in the fourth quarter.

The Badgers completed their National Collegiate Athletic Association-mandated suspensions by sitting out six players against the Wildcats, including their No. 1 receiver, Chris Chambers, and the all-American cornerback Jamar Fletcher. They were among 26 players who got caught receiving unadvertised discounts at a shoe store.
Michigan 35, Illinois 31
Anthony Thomas scored on a 3-yard run with less than three minutes left as No. 10 Michigan took advantage of two late fumbles to beat No. 19 Illinois in Champaign, Ill.
Just before the touchdown, Thomas appeared to fumble near the goal line, but officials ruled he was down. A replay appeared to show otherwise.

The Wolverines rallied from a 21-7 deficit in the third quarter behind Drew Henson. After missing the first three games with a broken right foot, Henson replaced an ineffective John Navarre at quarterback late in the second quarter.
Thomas rushed for 228 yards and 2 touchdowns to help the Wolverines (3-1, 1-0 Big Ten) avoid a repeat of last week's close loss at U.C.L.A.
The Illini (3-1, 0-1) missed a chance at the program's best start since 1951.
Nebraska 42, Iowa 13
Eric Crouch threw 5 touchdown passes on 10 completions and also ran for 93 yards as No. 1 Nebraska survived an early scare at home.
Crouch was 10 of 13 for 159 yards, while Iowa (0-4) matched a school record with its 12th straight loss.
Dan Alexander ran for 113 yards and Correll Buckhalter had 100 yards for the Cornhuskers (3-0).
Florida State 31 Louisville 0
Linebacker Tommy Polley returned an interception 4 yards one touchdown and forced a fumble to set up another as No. 2 Florida State (4-0) extended major college's longest winning streak to 16 games.
Chris Weinke threw for 221 yards and a touchdown, ran 2 yards for another, but was intercepted three times in Tallahassee, Fla.
Florida 59, Kentucky 31

Florida quarterback Jesse Palmer accounted for five touchdowns, four of them rushing to tie a school record, as the third-ranked Gators built a five-touchdown lead and beat visiting Kentucky for the 14th consecutive time.

Palmer scored on two 1-yard sneaks, an inside bootleg from 14 yards and a quarterback scramble from 13 yards. He also threw a 32-yard touchdown pass during a 49-second scoring burst that gave Florida (4-2, 2-0 Southeastern Conference) control of the game.

Behind the 275-pound quarterback Jared Lorenzen, who was 35 of 59 for 363 yards, 2 touchdowns and 2 interceptions, Kentucky (2-2, 0-1) piled up 504 yards, the most by any S.E.C. team against Florida since Steve Spurrier took over as coach in 1990.
Miami 47 West Virginia 10
Ken Dorsey threw two touchdown passes to Reggie Wayne and No. 12 Miami's defense scored three times at West Virginia.
Miami (2-1, 1-0 Big East), which allowed 34 points in a loss at Washington two weeks ago, held the Mountaineers to 95 yards in the first half and 317 over all.
For West Virginia, (2-1, 1-1) quarterback Brad Lewis was just 11 of 31 for 113 yards and Avon Cobourne, the Big East's leading rusher, sat out with a sprained ankle.
Southern Cal 34 San Jose State 24

Carson Palmer led a late Southern Cal rally as the No. 9 Trojans scored three touchdowns in the final 8:07. Petros Papadakis bulled 5 yards up the middle for the go-ahead score with 2:34 remaining as host Southern Cal (3-0) came back from a 12-point deficit.
Palmer, who completed 22 of 38 for 338 yards and 2 touchdowns, threw to Matt Nickels for the 2-point conversion and a 3-point lead over the Spartans (2-2).
South Carolina 23 Mississippi State 19
Erik Kimrey threw a 25-yard fourth-quarter touchdown pass on his first play of the game, lifting host South Carolina over No. 25 Mississippi State (2-1, 0-1 S.E.C.).
The Gamecocks (4-0, 2-0) entered the season with a 21-game losing streak.
Purdue 38, Minnesota 24
Drew Brees set Big Ten career records for completions and attempts, throwing for 409 yards and 2 touchdowns for No. 21 Purdue (3-1, 1-0 Big Ten) at home.
Brees, who was 33 of 49, topped the marks of 797 completions set by Jack Trudeau of Illinois and 1,309 attempts by Mark Herrmann of Purdue.
Brees has 1,325 attempts, 820 completions, 9,487 yards and 73 touchdown passes in 36 games. He also rushed for a career-high 88 yards, including an 11-yard touchdown for Purdue's final score.
Clemson 31, Virginia 10
Quarterback Woodrow Dantzler ran for 220 yards and 2 long touchdowns for No. 11 Clemson (4-0) in Charlottesville, Va.
Kansas State 55 North Texas 10
Quarterback Jonathan Beasley scored a school-record five touchdowns for No. 4 Kansas State (4-0) in Manhattan, Kan.
IN OTHER GAMES

LaDainian Tomlinson, who entered the game as the nation's leading rusher, ran for 140 yards and 2 touchdowns to lead No. 18 TEXAS CHRISTIAN to a 52-3 victory over visiting ARKANSAS STATE. The Horned Frogs (3-0) have won eight consecutive games. . . . The backup quarterback Casey Clausen threw three touchdown passes in his first game, and Travis Henry and Travis Stephens ran for two scores each as No. 13 TENNESSEE (2-1) beat LOUISIANA-MONROE, 70-3. . . . At Norman, Okla., Quentin Griffin ran for 117 yards and 3 touchdowns as No. 17 OKLAHOMA (3-0) beat RICE, 42-14. Josh Heupel completed 27 of 35 passes for 324 yards and 2 touchdowns. . . . Ben Leard threw two touchdown passes and Rudi Johnson added a 56-yard scoring run late in the fourth quarter to lift No. 20 AUBURN to a 31-14 victory over visiting NORTHERN ILLINOIS. The Tigers are 4-0 for the first time since 1997. . . . Jeff Kelly passed for 257 yards and 2 touchdowns as No. 22 SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI beat host OKLAHOMA STATE, 28-6. Kelly threw a 31-yard touchdown pass to Shawn Mills in the first quarter and gave the Golden Eagles (2-1) a 21-3 lead with a 9-yarder to Mills in the third quarter. . . . Bruce Thornton ran for two touchdowns to lead No. 24 GEORGIA (2-1) to a 37-0 victory over visiting NEW MEXICO STATE. . . . No. 15 TEXAS (2-1) scored three touchdowns on turnovers and the Longhorns smothered one of the nation's best passing attacks in beating HOUSTON, 48-0.
COLLEGE FOOTBALL: ROUNDUP
